review_title: One of the best places you could work
pros: Supportive management Lots of room for learning new things Great work/life balance Leadership who take ownership
cons: Pay is not as high as it could be

pros:
Better pay than some competitors, treated with respect. Excellent facilities and supply chain/strategy. Invest in their management through training at corporate HQ, will fly you there & put you up in a hotel.

Hourly employees are treated very well and can do very well here if they can make their numbers and survive/avoid the standard workplace political game. When they work extra hours/shifts it's because they're asked, not told.
cons:
Demand quite a bit from management. Expected to work extra days/weekends for no compensation, threatened with it almost every week. Got to the point I'd almost just plan to work the weekend than be threatened with it every night.

I felt the upper management demanded answers come from lower/mid management because they didn't know themselves. Constantly pushing for excellence is good, but making the team feel inadequate every shift is not. 

Our facility won 1st place for the best DC in the nation, next night we were chewed out for "being complacent" because we had a tough night. That's when I decided to go.

pros:
The employees at my location were almost all very friendly, and for the most part happy where they were. The expectations were, generally reasonable, with some issues arising with overwork due to relatively high turnover.

Scheduling for me personally was very reasonable, and while there was some variability in my hours, it wasn't onerous.

The store where I worked was diverse in its hiring. Multiple trans employees (one whom I worked very closely with), multiple employees who were wheelchair-bound, as well as a variety of ethnicities and genders.
cons:
Safety. I was told multiple times to do things by a shift supervisor that were not only against Home Depot's own policies, but also against my better judgement. In the process of lifting heavy things and standing all day on concrete, I developed an inflammation in my hip joint. The company culture was to brush this under the rug, and I was forced to leave.

Management was still composed mostly of white men, including the store supervisor, most of the shift supervisors (at least the ones I worked with), and my own department supervisor.

- Change your schedule without notifying you, sometimes even scheduling you on days you request them not to put you on.

pros: I got a small pay raise when I switched from overnight freight to millwork. It was nice being the only person people could rely on for answers in the department, I felt important. I googled things every day to teach myself how to be better at this job. The two elderly workers who could rekey locks were my greatest support system. Free McDonalds and Taco Bell every few weeks to make it look like they care. Lots of ethnic diversity in this company. You can call the anonymous tip line if you see unsafe things happening and you will be taken seriously.
cons: There was absolutely zero help doing my job. Lifting +85lbs steel doors, huge triple pane windows, endless problematic orders from previously (untrained) specialists. Zero support from constantly rotating supervisors (who were clueless about the entire process), zero support from upper management. Ultimately it was a 1 man multi-department show. Constantly covering for lumber, hardware, service desk calls being routed because I was the only one answering the phone. Beyond overwhelming. Computers from 1999 that crashed in the middle of giant orders, or they deleted important files for customer orders. They kept trying to give me split days off, and didn't care I was a disabled veteran being run ragged. They also eliminated several department manager positions and instead have 4 people in charge of at least 3 departments each. They'll interview you for a supervisor position simply to boost their numbers, and you won't get the job because they've already filled the position. They prefer to promote non-Caucasian because they'll work harder and for less pay. They'll give you bravo awards instead of an actual raise. Sexual harassment is still prevalent as ever on night crew in particular.

review_title: Treated employees and veterans like they were worthless.

Watched the management that did treat employees respectfully and help their employees grow be forced out do to mistreatment of them.

Was not even an employee yet! I was in training for only 3 weeks when I realized that my brain could not handle it anymore. It was complete information overload and disorganized. My trainer looked like she was having a panic attack on several occasions as she was very overwhelmed which in turn made me and many others feeling uneasy. I decided that homedepot.com was not right for me and dropped out of the class. If you decide to take this course, be ready for chaos! Was hired through a contractor, First 2-3 weeks, not paid training, 6 hours a day Monday through Friday.. Wasted my time!!!!!

review_title: Opening lot is far easier than closing
pros: Free workout. 2 hours of vacation time accrual every month for part time and 4 for full time. 4 hours for holidays and 8 hours for full time. Works with your schedule. 401k available immediately. Some promotional opportunities available if you want to become full time. Free water and Powerade available to keep hydrated. 15 min breaks for every 2 hours worked. Holiday gifts from Home Depot. Profit sharing available to everyone including part time.
cons:
Dress code is sort of strict. As a lot associate, i sweat a lot. And making 13.50 an hour doesn’t afford me the opportunity to buy Home Depot shirts and it certainly doesn’t afford me the ability to have 2 collared shirts in a shift. I’m running around the lot in the middle of July in Georgia and you expect me to be able to afford 2 shirts per shift? 

They work me 5 days a week for part time on lot. It is grueling on your body and there is never enough help for loading in evenings. Feels like they load the morning crew on scheduling and when I start my shift, regular carts, 4 /6 wheelers / lumber carts are EVERYWHERE. There has to be a balance because this creates high turnover rates. It is very hard to run from garden getting wheat and pine straw and then run to the other side of the store to help get plywood and gyp board loaded and then run to the other side again to get 20 bags of mulch and run again to the pro side to get 10 bags of 80 lbs concrete. Minimal support and again high turn over rate is understandable in this position. Closing stock is 3 times more difficult than opening. Pass some of those duties on to the person opening. At my store, you have carts everywhere and the first part of my shift, I’m just trying to maintain. I work fast and very fit but even I have difficulties keeping up. Closing lot has to do all the trash in the front (including dumping), make sure the pine and wheat straw is presentable for customers, leaf blow the entire front and side of the store and make sure all carts are ready for customers in the morning. Add on to this loads and getting pine and wheat straw. I may move in the store to try to avoid lot duties. All of that for 13.50 an hour. If I’m being honest, for a 5 hour shift, sometimes I miss my 15 min break because there is no way to complete the tasks on time to be in a good position to get off.

job_title: Retail Sales Associate in Boulder, CO
pros:
Great Benefits with a must have 401k and Stock Purchasing Plan.

Also, except for a select few, almost all the employees there (management included) treat you like family. I only ever had issues with one employee in particular.

They are also VERY dedicated to treating their employees with respect, and DO NOT tolerate racism, sexism, hate speech, or ANY sexual harassment. I watched more than a few employees get fired over those types of misconduct in the workplace.
cons:
Unfortunately the pay wasn't up to what it should have been, but better than other retailers out there. 

Also, the upper store management had issues taking care of its long term employees as if we were still seen as "disposable" even though we had been there longer than almost everyone in the store. 

I was there 6.5 years and was the 7th longest-term employee there, alongside some associates who started working there when they retired from their other jobs. Out of 200+ employees at that particular store, it's not super great.

The work is hard, both on your body and mind. So many of the customers are atrocious and they just want you to baby them. I've worked food service before and even then I didn't get cussed out as often as I did working at the home depot. I've never worked somewhere where I'm treated like I'm subhuman as much as I have at The Home Depot. The garden and lumber departments are nothing but backbreaking labor and the service desk employees are almost always cashiers they taught to do 20x the work at the same pay. Cashier is tho only job I'd consider doing here, just don't be surprised when they either 1) ask you to do a bunch of work that is definitely not in your job description or 2) push you to smile through a customer trying to scam/flirt/degrade you. review_title: Job Offer Retracted - Come Sign Documents - And by the way we need start time of "earlier" than 3 am.
pros: Was offered job, and received confirmation of job offer. Appointment set to complete with specified documents requested.
cons:
Received offer for job. Appointment was set up to complete paperwork and screening with notification of specific documents needed to bring to appointment. 
Arrived to appointment, was asked to fill out availability for week, gave 10 & 12 hour hours each and every day for a total of 80 hours of availability.
Was told offer won't work out, need earlier hours. Giving an 8 am start time, questioned what is earlier, 3 am? Was told no, earlier. 
What a disappointing visit to what I was told a job offer to sign documents......and then told "it won't work", need "earlier" than a 3 am start time. Nothing else discussed - just availability. 
No care for people they may hire. Looking at solely availability (I offered 80 hours per week) instead of any qualifications, this company just wants bodies - any bodies.

review_title: Good Environment, Not So Great Management
job_title: Front End Associate/Cashier in Woodridge, IL
pros:
Great workplace culture, most everyone has a posisitve attitude, enjoy each other's presence, and seem like they want to be there.

Responsibilities are very straightforward. Not much to do other than check people out, sort shelves, or pick online orders. Pretty chill most of the time.
cons: Management has some pretty serious politics. Managers seem nice on the outside, but they've pulled some manipulative moves while I've been there, and often don't try very hard to give employees what they want. I tried switching to the hardware department once and they told me there weren't any openings. Then, a few weeks later they went up to one of my coworkers and randomly pulled him into the department! Other people have tried the same, only to be denied for reasons such as "I like you where I can keep track of you" (this was said to a 2-year employee with no record of misbehavior), or "yeah, you'd need to complete the online training first" (other associates have been pulled into the same department without even hearing of the online training!). They've got to clean up their act a bit if they want to keep everyone happy.

pros: Eyeglasses discounted with monthly payment
cons:
What an experience in life for me!
The company has a values wheel on everything, including the apron you wear.
So they live by it? Absolutely not.
I’ve never experienced so much bigotry and favoritism, especially from the front end supervisor who favors women.
It’s been my biggest regret working at THD, but I’m young enough to learn what I never want from a job again.

job_title: Front End Cashier in Cottonwood, AZ
pros:
The workers, truly golden, wonderful people who will be there for you when you need it, if you do the same. Wonderful camaraderie spirit for the most part, maybe just 1-2 sour apples. 
Also, you get recognized and appreciated for your hard work, which is awesome!
cons:
The system is all over the place, often incorrect about products in house, and sometimes it takes minutes to find barcodes for customers in line who you need to ring up, sometimes multiple times, which means you can spend 20 min with one customer, because they don’t care about finding a barcode for all of their different products- from screws and rebar to woods and siding. The system is vast and navigation can be a chore in a fast paced environment. 
Ease of actually helping customers and having someone to drive a forklift on hand at all times are necessities that unfortunately fall through the cracks often and make work life unnecessarily stressful. It’s hard to promote a company and services that often misplace BOPIS orders, miss rental requests, or do not have well organized online POS systems. Amidst the company chaos, they want you to navigate it with a smile and act like everything is fine and their world isn’t falling apart. Meanwhile, The Home Depot will continue to do nothing about updating the system or making things easier for the cashiers and customer service specialists to do their jobs correctly, timely, to the benefit of the customer with the quality they deserve, because - you guessed it: Corporate doesn’t care.

review_title: Great Work Environment with Nice Managers, but lazy people are able to stick around
pros: Management is generally very nice.  Managers keep employees in the loop on a daily basis on what is going on.  They keep safety as a top priority for everyone in the warehouse.  Also, they set up Ice Cream or Italian Ice or Food Truck Days quite often.  40 hours of Vacation is offered to all employees in the warehouse, but it is not available until after 6 months of employment.  The work environment is laid back, in fact sometimes too laid back!
cons:
The Lazy workers that hardly work, and goof off are able to stick around for a very long time, and generally nothing happens to them. Home Depot is a bit too relaxed on being willing to fire poor performing or lazy employees. This is truly a place where someone can come and "collect a paycheck" as long as they show up on time every day and work about 15% of their shift.   The hard workers carry the weight of the company, and get paid the same as the lazy workers who don't hardly do anything while they are there.  Half of the staff stands around and carries on long conversations, and also takes extra long breaks. This makes the hard working staff mad, and eventually the hard workers chill out and do less work themselves since there is no incentive to work hard for the same pay as the lazy workers!

Sick Time is only acrued at I believe 1.5 hours for every 40 hours worked, and you can't start to use it until after the 90 day mark of working there.  

The say you can obtain homer awards for extra money. Six homer awards is a $60 bonus, and then after that, every 10th homer award is a bonus. The problem is that they are very, very hard to get.  I have seen so few even handed out. I have worked there 9 months, and while I have received dozens of "bravos" and two "Caught Orange Handed" cards, I have yet to even receive a single Homer award. I have seen only about 6 of them handed out at the pre shift meetings since I started.

pros:
1- Paid vacation after 1 year.
2- Profit sharing paid out twice a year
3- Pay is ok.
4- Choice between day and night shift positions.
5- 401K with company match.
6- Paid sick time.
cons:
I only worked on the overnight team.
The job is OK until you can find something better, but I wouldn't recommend making a career out of it. If you don't have a car payment, and your single, or if both you and your spouse work, the job will hold you over until you can find something better. Otherwise, there's absolutely nothing fulfilling about the job. For starters, on the nightshift, you work 4 10 hour shifts, so for those four days the job takes over your life. Between working the shift, and getting rest, you have no time for your family until the end of the week, so your personal life is compressed into just 3 days of the week, Friday through Sunday. The job and the stress that comes with it, can be harmful to your health, both physically and mentally. My health suffered a great deal until I left. The company does offer health insurance, but the premiums for a policy that's useful, are so high, that it's not affordable. As a MET associate, you are second class. The stores don't respect you. For the most part, the stores treat you as if you dropped out of elementary school. The management, both at the store and corporate level can be very arrogant  I had done this type of work, with third party merchandising companies, but Home Depot had just simply taken all the enjoyment out of the job. As I said, it's an ok job to have for a while, but for the sake of your own health and well being, look for something better while you have this job.

review_title: Good for departments, terrible for front end
pros: I genuinely can't think of any.
cons:
This was probably the worst job I've ever had. I applied for the service desk associate position because they said they were hiring full time. When I was hired, they couldn't give me full time but promised that they would eventually. I worked there for almost two years and was never given full time. They did, however, often schedule me 34-36 hours a week to squeeze as much time out of me as possible without having to give me benefits. The wage was abysmal, the customers treated me like garbage, they were extremely short staffed which meant that I had to do many duties that were not in my job description, they had a terrible organizational system for online pickup and orders, and because I was there for the beginning of the pandemic the severity of these issues were escalated to an all new high. The departments seemed like a much better place to work with a lot more growth opportunities. But front end stuff? Awful. 

I can only hope that they've resolved these issues for newer employees.

pros: I'm assuming this varies for different locations but the one I was at had: very good benefits, descent pay, 2 bonuses per year, full 401k match. Actually, the retirement plan I picked, I got more than double what I was putting in. Most of the people were fun to work with. You can choose to have a 1/2 hour lunch or a 1 hour lunch even if you're new and part time. They actually encourage you to move up from your position. Paid sick leave, bereavement, & vacation. Part timers get all of that but the benefits get even better if you're full time. Usually lots of free food.
cons: It can be very stressful depending on your position. I did customer service so I dealt with plenty of angry customers. That was probably because I worked in a very busy location. It was a little too micromanaged. The managers are always trying to get you to get customers to take surveys which is very annoying but, I guess that's how it is at all of these places now.

review_title: Great people work here but job isn't great
job_title: Special Services Associate in Waukesha, WI
pros:
-If you are good at your job and management notices, you can easily be promoted. Management makes great money, but can come at a high personal cost. It's high stress being in HD leadership, but can be worth it for the salary.
-Great coworkers that I genuinely loved working with. HD has a diverse staff and most of the people I worked alongside were absolutely amazing.
-Rewards and parties happened often, but parties not so much during the height of COVID.
-Casual dress code was fantastic, but I did ruin some clothes since it's a warehouse you're working in.
-They hire you quickly, so there isn't a long hiring process.
-They provide you with employee training online and one on one time with your department supervisor or a leader. 
-There's decent discounts they give you for other companies and other random benefits available.
cons:
-No employee discount of any kind for store merchandise, not even snacks or drinks.
-Pay was way too low. When I worked there we were paid $12 an hour, which wasn't fair compensation for how hard the department worked.
-I worked a customer service role behind a desk, but there was way more physical labor than expected. If you have physical problems of any kind, I wouldn't recommend this company. 
-Outdated systems that constantly stopped working. Only way to fix it most of the time was to call IT and be on the phone waiting and being transferred for 2 hours sometimes.
-Especially depending on what role you have or certifications you earn, there are many potential hazards. There's sawdust in the air, machinery being used, extremely heavy products in the store, and a lot going on since it's a working warehouse. 
-The customers at my store were entitled and abusive to workers. I have worked other customer service jobs and it wasn't as bad as my time here. I was screamed at every single day and dealt with so many difficult customers. Management would help us out, but would give in to appease unruly customers. Instead of holding their ground and backing us up, customers would get their way and this created a vicious cycle. These people knew they could act horribly and get their way, which was extremely hard for us in customer service. 
-There was never enough staff in other departments. People in my department had to do tasks and help customers in departments we weren't familiar with. We had to constantly step away from the Special Services desk when we were already swamped.
-The Special Services department has way too much on their plate. Most other retail stores have several departments making up all the responsibilities we had! There was always an extremely long line because we were in charge of curbside orders, returns, in-store sales transactions, online orders, pro customer orders (due to the pro desk's limited hours), customer service and assistance, will call orders, answering and transferring all incoming store calls, delivery issues, order picking, loading large items for customers, and more.
On top of that, we had to support other departments. People don't last long at the Special Services desk because we are in charge of too many tasks and are expected to take on others. The Service Desk should be broken up into several departments to alleviate the stress on employees and for the customer experience. If you're interested in working for Home Depot, work in any other department besides Special Services. It's a thankless, underpaid job that will kill your body and break your sanity.

job_title: Freight Team Associate in Atlanta, GA
pros: Knowledge of seasoned staff is what runs these stores. You will meet folks of all ages, and walks of life. Transferring to another store is easy if your records are clean. I'm currently at my third store Generally a friendly atmosphere between coworkers in comparison to other work places.
cons: As result of pandemic many people have experienced much loss, inspiring career/family adjustments. People are simply reevaluated their careers. The stores cannot thrive without the complimentary knowledge of experienced associates. Home Depot gave bonuses throughout the pandemic. Once that ended they gave a $1 raise to all associates in early 2021, with an additional $1 raise late 2022. Many associates make minimum wage, so a $2 raise is greatly appreciated. However, the customers are more on edge, demanding, and disrespectful than ever post-pandemic. Corporate makes their money, but the handful of workers left who see HD as a career are fading under the increased pressure. I had to change to the graveyard shift for a bit of peace from customers.

job_title: Merchandising Execution Team in Rochester, MI
pros: As someone who prides myself in my DIY/home improvement knowledge, working at Home Depot only furthers that skill-set and knowledge base. Everyone who works the customer side is provided several weeks of formal training in their department which is great for passing on to customers, and even other employees. Speaking of passing on knowledge with other employees, for the most part, I've really enjoyed all of my coworkers that I've had throughout the years working at HD. Most are genuinely down-to-Earth and nice people, which is saying something based on other jobs I've held (construction, auto garage, video store, etc.)
cons: Underpaid. I thoroughly believe that during my time working sales/customer side of Home Depot and working MET, the amount of work you are expected to do is significantly more tasking than working any other part-time retail job. At this point, due to Covid, I believe employees are making a min. of $14-15? But when I was there, I made $11/hour to bust my butt.

pros:
Good physical work (stay in shape)
little training required
few if any work experience required
Good options and deals associated with employment (financial plans and health care)
It was a great way to maintain my physical fitness when I was not overexerting myself, and pay was great in terms of effort when the days were light. Peers were nice to work with and general work environment was good, both to customers and to asociates.
cons:
Depends on management
Depends on customers
Can be quite difficult to keep stamina up based on weather (summer heat, rain, ice, ect.)
My experience (with management and customers) showed that work was inconsistent, sometimes I worked with exclusively pro customers and contractors, sometimes with hobbists and DIY people. You are expected to help customers load and unload material and merchandise, which sometimes can be quite difficult if the customer or other associates cannot or will not help. Being not allowed to take tips was also quite annoying, as loading 30 bags of 50 lb concrete was exhausting, and then continuing work of the same degree throughout the day made 10$ per hour seem unworthy of the effort required.

job_title: Appliance Sales in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
I loved working here for the almost 8 years I was there in appliance sales. I started going to college half way through my employment and the HR department and management were extremely supportive. When I was originally hired here I was in a dire financial situation at only 20 years old with very little skills and no resources including being homeless. HD brought me in at a fair hourly pay and provided great training. They have great benefits, 401k, and stock options, all of which I took advantage of. The most meaningful benefit HD provided me was the opportunity to work part-time and go to college. Once I graduated, I left because I started off my career, and 4 years later I can say I have a great job in my field of study with a fantastic salary. I couldn't have accomplished what I have now without a flexible job opportunity like the one I had at HD.

Many of my co-workers complained about working conditions at HD, but I can honestly say that it's all what the individual makes of it. If you're a good employee with a positive attitude you will be fine. Don't get involved in work politics or gossip, and remain professional and strictly business at all times even if you're just a cashier or sales associate like me. I did this and was fine.
cons: Work politics, customers in this particular area were sometimes difficult or rude.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Opportunities to advance, training, very physically demanding and I lost 80 lbs. working there.
cons: Have to be willing to play the political game to advance. I said bad timing because I only worked there during the pandemic. We were severely under staffed where I would be working 3-4 departments a day. At one point I was working 6 days a week but they would claim it was my own fault when I would be scheduled 9 days in a row. Sometimes expected to work 10-12 hour shifts. I ended up working a 16 hour shift one night. Very physically demanding and mentally demanding. When customers have complaints and would ask to speak to a manager, half the time my managers would tell me to handle it myself. Customers were disgusting pigs, I worked in a male dominated department and male customers thought it was okay to put their hands on me multiple times. I went to management several times and asked for help and they told me to 'be assertive' but 'not too mean'.
